they use an old plain cheese pizza that has been rotating on a heat rack -which comes to you like its been HOURS on the rack-after they throw your toppings on long enough to cook those-by which the rest of the cheese, OLD, pizza is practically burnt... this place SUCKS! 

plus i found a gummy, rice string on one of my slices--do not order here. wayyyy better pizza than this! shut their disgusting doors!
author: Hungry H.

description: JUST had pizza delivered (haven't even looked at it yet), but have to review the delivery service! They call to say the pizza is downstairs?????? Fucking ring our bell and come up bitch!  Seriously??? Ugh, if Georgio's was open today I wouldn't have even dared calling anyone else, but as they closed early I  was giving someone else a try. Poo on me!! I hope its eatable.
author: Gary T.

description:
My poor husband. He had a quick slice here yesterday while waiting for me and about 2 hours later he was sick as a dog. It was the only thing he ate that I didn't in the past few days so we know it had to be the pizza. He's been sick for over 24 hours with no end in sight. 

Poor guy.  I've literally never seen anyone so sick. 

I never thought pizza could make anyone *THIS* sick. Clearly the Village Pizzeria has some cleanliness issues as his doctor suspects it's LISTERIA.

Not fun :-( 

Save yourself the pain.... LITERALLY.
author: AceGirl ..

description: After trying to get in touch with our usual pizza deliver place, we decided to try Village Pizza. This place is great!! The pizza came quick and was uber-delicious! I will definitely order from Village Pizza again!
author: Tabatha O.

description:
This is a delivery experience, and my only experience with Village pizzeria.

So why two stars? The delivery pasta that I just finished eating was NOT great. The delivery was timely, the delivery guy courteous, however if you're looking for a delicious meal that happens to have spaghetti or fettuccine anywhere in the title, I'd suggest you look elsewhere. The balognese sauce was weak flavored and the chicken in our fettuccine tasted processed.

Would I give it another shot? Yes. However I'd go for back for the pizza... However, with North Beach pizza AND pizza orgasmica in the same neighborhood, its going to have to be some frickin' SERIOUS pizza to steal me away. And for Italian, being this close to gaspare's you're also really going to have to kill it. 2 stars for the food, 4 stars for the fast and courteous delivery.
author: John M.

description:
I tried two pizzerias today. 

This is the first of two.

I enjoyed their nine-inch pesto pizza.

It was satisfying and rich in its simplicity.

Parking is crappo around here.  I did find spaces off Arguello.
author: Derek N.

description:
Village Pizzeria has been in business since 1979 as they boast on their wall & on their boxes. With 28 years of experience, I expect much more...

After I returned from my bike ride, I decided to load up on some carbs & play couch commando for the rest of the afternoon. I had eaten a slice from Village Pizzeria before, and evidently forgot how much it sucked. I stepped outside my apartment, walked half a block & ordered a pepperoni calzone to go. 

The counter person was extremely friendly, and mentioned that my order would be ready in 20 minutes. So I wandered my neighborhood for a few & then returned to pick up my grub. 

The calzone was HUGE! I was excited about that. I wanted some extra marinara sauce for dipping, and she informed me it would cost $0.50! This was after I had already paid $12 and tipped her a dollar even though it was a to go order. I can't stand it when restaurants pull the 'we're gonna charge you extra for 2oz of sauce because we don't put enough on our food'. 

Annoyed, I brought the calzone home & started to eat. It was extremely bland, with not nearly enough pepperoni for its size. I was very disappointed in my whole experience, especially the surcharge for their mediocre sauce that should have been free.

Only reason this place gets 2 stars is because of the friendly employee. At least they can hire halfway decent people.

If you're hungry, I have leftovers. They will be waiting for you in my trash can.
author: matt m.

description: This was one of the most disgusting pizzas I have ever had. The taste was gag inducing, and I had to open the windows just to get the foul smell out of the apartment. Wish I could get my 30 bucks back. Should have trusted my instincts when I noticed no one was in the restaurant.
author: R V.

description:
I've decided that finding anything close to my beloved NY pizza in SF is an exercise in futility. It's a bit like trying to have an orgasm after you've been drinking for 10 hours: you can get close to it, but it's probably not going to happen.

EDIT: Ordered from Village Pizzeria a few weeks ago and got a slice of their siciian along with my medium mushroom. I still think the crust is a little too buttery to be NY style, but the sicilian slice was awesome. Most pizzerias in SF don't do sicilian, so it's nice to have the option! I would go for that instead.
author: Maria D.

description:
I came here the first time my first week of college, then forgot where it was for two years. Then, when I returned from living in Budapest, I found it again.

For a week, my friend Annie and I were not going to be groceries, we were just going to eat in cheap restaurants. Well, the plan lasted for only a week, but this was part of our collection of cheap eats that I think is still very good pizza.

If you want a really thin crust pizza, this is the place. I only have gotten the cheese slices here, but I really like it. If you are with a big group of people, you want to just eat a slice and read a magazine, or get delivery, this is a great place for all three. 

They also have other locations in the city as well. I am giving them a four, but I think it should really be a 3.5. It is consistent and tasty, it is just missing the extra .5 to make it a full four.
author: Christopher W.

description: Come on ... a delivery pizza.  How badly can you really screw it up in 20 mins? When the pizza arrived, it looked like it had stood on its side.  We called up and couldn't get a manager (they were out?).  They did deliver another, but no apology, and didn't offer a refund.  Not exactly great customer service.  Oh well, I should have stuck with Georgio's :-)
author: Matt D.

description:
Every time I come here, I always have to decide whether to get a Neapolitan (thin crust) or Sicilian (thick crust) pizza! To make things easier for me, I usually get a thick slice of pepperoni and a thin slice of mushrooms with roma tomatoes and I'm set. I like my thin slice the best because the mushroom and tomatoes are so fresh! Sometimes, I will have the soup du jour and a small house salad in addition to my pizza slices which taste okay, nothing special. 

I was hangover on Saturday and was craving for some really good (crispy, hot, drench in sauce) buffalo wings. Hooters was suggested from other Yelpers, but it was already 8pm and I was too lazy to drive all the way down to the Wharf. 

Then, I realized that most pizza places have buffalo wings on their menu so I searched the "take-out menu" cabinet in the kitchen and pulled out Village Pizzeria's menu! My boyfriend and I decided to order a few things to share: 12 pieces of spicy buffalo wings, bowl of soup (cream of potatoes) with house salad (vinaigrette dressing) and garlic roll. After 45-minutes, our food arrived, only to find out that they forget to give us our soup and salad. We called Village P and they were really apologetic and by the time the delivery man brought the rest of our food, we've finished eating the wings. Everything we ordered tasted good, but I wished they all arrived at the same time. I guess next time I'll know to check my order before the delivery person leaves :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
Dear god no.

Ingrediants taste like they are blended together.

Over an hour for a pie, with their online ordering system.

After three tries, I've finally learned my lesson. No more.
author: Darrell L.

description: We ordered for delivery about a month ago for the first time (we usually go there to eat) The delivery took over an hour and we live in the neighborhood. The lady who brought it was really rude and disrespectful when we complain about how late we got our order. The pizza was cold and dry, we couldn't even eat it!! After calling about five times to talk to the manager or owner, i gave up...seems like no one is in charge of this place. Last week, we decided to go dine in and give it another try. They changed the servers!!! Customer service is really bad now, horrible! that guy needs to work on his customer service skills and learn to smile. I don't even think he can understand English, it was really frustrating. We are not coming here again, better Giorgios  or pizza orgasmica which are a couple of blocks down
author: Sara B.

description:
Ah, Village Pizza...yum. Yummy yum. The right sauce, the right cheeses, and yes kids, the right friggin' pizza dough.

The oasis in the desert of SF pizza, Village is yet another business started by a native of Brooklyn, NY (sense a trend here?), who came to SF and filled a need. Thankfully! 

I keep hearing how this or that joint serves "great NY pizza". I go, I taste...I'm left wanting. The sauce, people!!! The biggest mistake made by pizza makers is in the sauce. If it's too garlicky (often the case), it dies. Most pizza sauces are too spicy in general. The sauce should be slightly tangy-sweet. The other is cheese. Only the right blend of cheeses works, and too often we get one left out, or something else substituted. Ugh! And even if it's not thin crust, the sauce and cheese has to be correct, or else it just don't work. Thin crust is preferred, though. And a little oil should drip off!

Besides all of that, the place has been recently remodeled, and there's good sandwiches, too. They have a nice selection of beverages, including Dr. Brown's Black Cherry, which I occasionally will slurp down, because it's all natural.

I wish they had a veal parmigiana sandwich on the menu, because then I'd eat there even more often. That, however, is a minor quibble.

There is another VP on Van Ness, which is slightly more expensive (guess the rent is higher), but also killer. There used to be a 3rd one in the Marina, but it closed several years ago. Too bad!
author: ACE A.

description:
5 stars for the calzone. 1 star for the regular thin crust. I don't want to average it out, though, since the calzone is all I care about.
 If you are familiar with me and my  eating habits (or you just like to stalk me on Yelp), you will know that 6 days out of the week, I have the appetite of a baby bird and that one glorious day  a week, it somehow all catches up to me and I devour mass quantities of cheesy, saucy anything and mashed potatoes and chocolate cake and yes, it's disgusting but hey-  that's  me.

In any event, this calzone is to die for. Get the pepperoni and garlic and you will be rewarded with the most delicately-crusted, most light and lucious (yes- LIGHT pizza), most perfectly sauced and cheesed enormous crescent of pizza goodness on earth. Or at  least in San Francisco. 

As far as the rest of the menu goes, I don't know. And I can't comment on delivery since we chose pick up. All I can say  is that both my miniature companion and my fully matured companion did not walk away  from that monster (it's huge) without sauce and stupid grins on their faces. This will be my go-to place for my massive pigout day  from here on out. Even if I do have to drive across town to get it.
author: Autumn K.

description:
I will start by saying that delivery from this place is awful.

I ordered a pizza with garlic, spinach and mushrooms on it around 8:30pm. At 10:00 I had to call to ask where it was. About 20 minutes later the pizza finally showed up. 

It was completely cold. I mean, literally, the cheese was as hard as if it had been sitting out for an hour already. And on top of that, I asked them to send lots of parmesan cheese with it, and none was sent at all.

I will never order from them again.
author: Elly S.

description:
We should have seven different words for pizza like the Eskimos have so many words for snow.  If you are raised on pizza in Chicago, you will form one impression of this staple food.  If you then ask for it in New York, you will be confused at the strangely thin crust and the relatively even balance between dough and topping.  You may even reject the idea that it is pizza at all.  

Generally, in California, you will get some version in between and it will usually have broccolini or artichoke hearts or capers or excessive sun dried tomatos.  In my book, this is not pizza.  It may be good, but it deserves its own word.

I will come clean at this juncture.  I am a transplant from the greater New York/New Jersey metropolitain area.  I fold my pizza in half after sprinkling it with garlic salt and sometimes red pepper flakes.  When you have been raised on this kind of pizza and you consume it this way, it is sublime.

If you are like me, you will appreciate Village Pizzeria for their true-to-form thin crust deliciousness.  If you order a "plain" pizza, they will understand you.  (What is "cheese" pizza anyway?)  If you are from the Chicago or California School of pizza, you will probably be disappointed, but then I don't think you're their target customer, and you should probably find your own word for the food anyway.
author: Mike M.

description:
either I was super hungry or this place serves a mean NYC style cheese pizza by the slice.
upon reflection, I would have to say YES on both counts.
author: Jeff W.

description:
A native New Yorker (and thus parochial pizza snob) I am a fan of Village Pizza and pretty much consider this the best slice in SF. Good thin crust, nice sauce, and yes, the variety of shakers (oregano, red pepper, parmesan and most important, garlic) helps. Their Monday-Thursday pitchers specials are good too, though I sorely miss the days when Red Tail was only $3 a pitcher! (up to $6.50 now...)

If you really want to get the best out of your pizza, ask them to bake whole pies so the crust is extra crispy. If ordering slices this usually isn't necessary since the reheating takes care of that (getting slices is really the best way to enjoy pizza).

I noticed people were disappointed with take out from here. I'm not surprised - even my favorite NY pizzerias disappoint with takeout. In defense of Village and any other pizzeria I say this: do not judge a pizza parlor based on delivery. Although everyone orders pizza for delivery, it's not the way it was meant to be eaten - a slice, reheated and fresh out of the oven - that's the way it should be.
author: Nicko G.

description: Horrible Pizza and service! the cheese pizza nothing but tomato sauce and crust hardly any cheese even you pay for extra cheese! their Margherita pizza using green onions instead of basil talk about DIRT CHEAP!
author: Ryu K.

description:
Surprisingly inconsistent reviews here.  I am going to theorize that the quality of your pie might be contingent on who is working.  I just tried it for the first time tonight and was pleasantly surprised -- the crust was crunchy and floury and didn't sag like the typical impotent pizza so typical in California.  The toppings were good quality.  We ordered a veggie.  I will say the sauce was lacking and watery, but I find most pizzas here to be lacking in sauce and what sauce there is is thin.

If I can't make it to Polk St or Kearney, then this is my 3rd favorite in SF so far.
author: Eric X.

description: They deliver beer & wine - 'nuff said!
author: Gina G.

description:
My girlfriend and I split a Village Special Pizza, but forgot to order the thin crust.  The combo of ingredients was good, and the thick crust was not too bad either.  I think our timing was bad as it was our first time here and  there happened to be two boys soccer teams celebrating after a game, so it was a bit of a zoo.  I could barely even hear my Gfriend talking.  

Anyway, I would like to try their thin crust pizza, but it's not high on my list to come back.
author: km k.

description:
3.5 star review.  
I ate in the restaurant and was pleased to see paper plates and paper cups - pizza should not be fancy.  (Still, it'd be nice if they figured out something a little more environmentally friendly).  The staff was very accommodating and prices were reasonable.  

Everything seemed to be made from scratch - it look about 1/2 an hour for our hot wings to be served, but they were worth the wait.  We got 3 thin crust pizzas (the Hawaiian, the village special and a vegetarian.).  I enjoyed pizzas, but we had to wait for them as well.
author: She-Ra ..

description: Delicious. I had the Carnivore's Delight pizza. The server was nice too.
author: Dale K.

description: Mmmmm...meh. Clam and garlic slice, Sicilian style, and a Mirror Pond. Moms and kids seem to like this place for some reason.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I LOVE the Chef's Special pizza!!! Fresh mozz, basil, tomato, parmesean, olive oil. Perfect. 

To me, it wasn't the typical margherita pizza - its all melded together, the basil is added after the oven, and I love it. Did I say that already?

Decent price, delivery has always been good - 40 min. on average, but I'm only 7 blocks away. 

I went with a New Jersey native, and she said that it felt / tasted like a place she'd eat at there. I've never been, so I can't back it up - but I'll take her word for it. 

Yum... I just ate - but its making me hungry thinking about this deliciouso pizza pie.
author: Alexa S.

description:
I generally come in here when giorgios is too crowded and I need food ASAP. But I'm always disappointed. The pizza is consistently soggy, which isn't really acceptable after waiting 30+ minutes for them to make it when the place is mostly empty. despite the sogginess, the pizza doesn't taste bad, but that doesn't really matter when the whole thing is soggy.

Other than that, their pesto cheese bread is good.
author: Allyson S.

description:
I think most people get take out because this place is always empty.  The few times I've seen it full are when it was crawling with middle schoolers after a CYO basketball practice.  Ahhh, I miss those days.

Very decent pizza at a reasonable price.  On Thursday's they have 5 dollar pitchers if you order food which is a great deal.  I'd stay away from the Sandwiches though.
author: Patrick N.

description: crust is great, sauce is well flavoured, cheese is nicely balanced! i always order spinach, feta, garlic, basil, and sometimes pesto sauce.
author: Chris F.

description:
I can't believe nobody has mentioned the Garlic Clam pizza!  While I wouldn't normally order such a thing, I was here one day browsing the menu, and the Garlic Clam just sounded . . . interesting.  I LOVED it.  My sister, sitting across the table from me, was less impressed.  "Could you please stop breathing in my general direction." I believe she said.  Don't eat this pizza with a date if you plan to kiss him/her in the next 24 hours, but definitely try it.  My sister ordered the pepperoni, which did look greasy but tasted delish.   They have relatively cheap beer, too, which always goes great with pizza.  

I've eaten in the place twice and had delivery to my house once.  All three experiences made me happy.
author: Gaping F.

description: I'm sorry to say I haven't tried the pizza yet... But I will share my love for their pesto-cheese bread!! It is wonderful. I love pesto and I love cheese, so why not!  I'm hoping the pizza is just as good... Will update later when I finally try it.
author: Dijonne M.

description: Great NY style pizza by the slice. The pizza really is excellent ( and I'm from NYC too). A+
author: Dee K.

description: Best Pizza in the city hands down. It is east cost style so you gots to like thin crust.    They also have a little pizza by the slice store in the Rincon Center if you work down town.
author: Joe D.

description:
My boyfriend found a piece of METAL in his pizza!!!  This was after it took 2 1/2 hours to get it delivered because they delivered to the wrong address!!!   Do you think he should sue?  We still have the metal broken in two pieces after he bit it.  

BAN THIS ESTABLISHMENT!!!
author: Elaine G.

description:
I went to this pizzeria for dinner after going to a Meetup function at the Presidio this past Sunday.  This restaurant is in a nice location just down the hill from the Presidio.  I went down there for dinner because I was in the mood for pizza.  Their menu has several gourmet pizzas that are Italian-style pizzas and not American-style pizzas.  It is the type that you would eat with a fork and knife. and doesn't have too much cheese or crust.

The crowd wasn't too big on a Sunday so it would be good to go for a quiet date.  I will definitely check this place out again next time I am in the city.
author: Jonathan K.

description: Thought this was going to be another crappy pizza place in the area, but i really enjoyed what i got actually.  Thick-style, basic ingredients, exactly what i was looking for.  I'll definitely be coming back here again.
author: Phil J.

description: thursday lucky find....$six.fifty pitcher deal....was it $five.fifty?..still a bargain drink...mention beer first and pizza second....thickest of sicilian pizza....thick meaty village special....pizza choice including loved anchovies!....two "blocks" and full...three "blocks" and overkill....thinner neapolitan a more manageable pizza pie...thinner and finer standard slicing bites....order a side of moist buffalo wings tasty....beer, wings and pizza!....heaven food!.....
author: Hen A.

description:
This was grim. We'd just moved in to the neighborhood and were hoping that this, the closest pizza to us, would give ys years of take-out bliss.

First glaring sign something was wrong: when I asked her (server/cashier) which was her favorite slice, she replied "I guess they're all pretty good". 

The quality of the pizza lined up perfectly with her level of enthusiasm for the product: mediocre to blah. 

The spinach salad was good, though. 

Time to try Nizario's and Giorgio's.
author: r g.

description:
naively i went to new york based on that song by sinatra and the posters they used to have at the marina location. i went on a date here with a german tourist in 09 and we should have gotten slices one pizza was like 30 bucks man

i could go for a sicilian today
author: Kimmy J.

description: I thought this place had potential.  It smelled great from outside which enticed us in the door.  The prices here are rather high but it is SF so I get it.  The salad selection looked nice until you seen the price, over $10 for a large salad, ugh.  We went with a medium pizza, one topping and a garden salad.  The ranch dressing was boring with no flavor and the salad was just lettuce, tomato, cucumber and olives.  The garlic roll was decent but a little on the hard side.  The pizza was nothing special at all, thinish crust with pepperoni and skimpy cheese.  The restaurant itself is nice inside, they have beer on tap and nice big windows to people watch.  I agree with this rating description 'Meh.  I've experienced better!'
author: La C.

description: Not the best pizza in town, but serviceable.  I'll give them credit for delivery, serving beer, and putting together a decent thin crust pie.  That being said, you are better off walking down the street to Giorgio's in my opinion.
author: Matt G.

description:
Finally!  Love this pizza!!!! I am from the east coast and finding really great pizza has been a challenge but I was so pleasantly surprised.  Crust has that great crunch with soft insides, homemade sausage that has just the right amount of fennel... so tasty.... sauce is not overwhelming ...just the right amount and of course cheese... just the right amount.

My go to pizza place!
author: Carol F.

description: I was born and raised in NY and have traveled the country extensively. In general, I give SF pizza a B to B+. I have had everything from Escape to Ameci's to Zante's to Golden Boy to North Beach to....well you get the picture. Village really is the best pizza in SF. Thin crust as it should be, not too much cheese, not cooked unevenly, not dripping with oils. It's tight! And consistent. I order from these folks every 6 weeks or so and never get a bad pizza. I highly recommend the Clam and Garlic!
author: Byrne B.

description: I was in a rush to grab a bite to eat. Good that they make the pizza fresh but once I got home I started eating and all I can say is WATER!!!!!.....Salty and oily.
author: Calvin C.

description: Few places do a Scicillian this good, and I haven't found another pizzaria that can do a clam, garlic and pesto like this place. Great location and a nice layout with a classic look finishes this place nicely. Staff was cool, quick and friendly. Restrooms are shared with other businesses in the building and are in need of some TLC, but don't let stop you.
author: Tristan C.

description: Order online if you want the pesto variety of calzone - I decided to get delivery from here again but called directly this time.  I'm okay with the fact that they didn't have the cheese tortellini w/garlic sauce (grrrr) and the ham sandwich I got in place of it looks and smells promising, but this time the calzone had marinara inside instead of pesto.  Nothing against marinara, but the pesto is soooo much better.  Anyway, just FYI.
author: Sus... B.

description: mehhh. everytime i came here the crust was burnt.
author: AL S.

description: The best part of this place is that you can enjoy any pizza in slice form. I love the chef's special and their salads are delicious. They make their dressings from scratch and I usually have to order both the vinaigrette and the italian because I can never decide which I like more. Greek salad is superb- the only downfall is that the tomatoes are a bit old sometimes. Anytime I want pizza now, this is my go to place.
author: Robin L.

description: I like this place, I know my hubby does too. Thin crust is the way to go and the ubiquitous antipasto salad as well. The thin crust is pretty good, and the toppings are nice. Always good service and that local-hoody feel make this place a great old standby. Our favorite thing to do is order something like sausage and peppers with anchovies thrown in and then not finish it all, bring the pizza home, let it get cold, then heat it up slice by slice in a nonstick skillet on medium to low heat till the crust gets crispy and the cheese starts oozing. If you're gonna have pizza left overs and then heat it up, Village's pizza is the best because no where else are you gonna find a pizza that's just as good, if not better, the second time around.
author: cora j.

description:
i know in my reviews i throw around the fact that i am still a new yorker cuz once a new yorker always a new yorker, its in your blood even if you have been living elsewhere for forever, blah, blah, blah....and yet....when you have new york pizza in your blood you just can't shake the love!

not saying that i am not blessed 10 fold to have deja vu pizza in my corner of the mish. but deja vu is cream-o-the-crop california pizza and village pizzeria is cream-o-the-crop california new york style pizza. ya get me?

thin just the right amount of crispy crust, perfect amount of sauce (not a lot), drippy, juicy cheesiness on top, nice and hot!

one star down for....well, its kinda my fault for ordering a brownie at a pizzeria.....the brownies are beautiful on the outside but dull and dry on the inside.

excellent service, good prices, totally going back!
author: Bad Ass Chic K.

description: Village Pizzeria has the best pizza I've ever eaten outside of New Jersey. 'Nuff said.
author: Josh O.

description: I rarely miss the East coast. The snow in the winter, the humidity in the summer, the "Newenglandah" attitude. But the public transportation and the pizza, those things I pine for. In any city kissing the Atlantic, this is not a 4-star joint, but out here, Village Pizzeria will at least take the edge of the jones for the real stuff. The crust is a little cardboardy, but still better than much of the competition. The online ordering works like a charm; we always get a follow up call within a very few minutes. And strangely, for someone who's something of a traditionalist when it comes to pizza toppings, I think the Bit of Bacon (with, of all things, ranch dressing, tomatoes, and piles of garlic) is totally yummy. It doesn't make up for the lack of an excellent subway system, but I enjoy it nonetheless.
author: Martha S.

description:
i call to place an order, and the person at the restaurant answers only with "hello".  for a split second i wonder if i've misdialed, and am bothering someone at home.  i had to ask if it was the pizzeria, to which she responded by letting out a huge sigh, and then she said "yes" for so long, it became two syllables. 

 i order the meat lasagna, house salad, and a 2L of coke.

 45 minutes later, said order arrives.

 i open the lasagna container and see two small lumps trapped under a hardened coat of cheese. it's so hard, i have to cut it with a knife to remove a portion--and i mean full-on lumberjack-with-saw motion... i take a bite, and the sauce is so salty, i almost down the whole 2L of coke i bought. 

 hiding a few noodles under a slab of cheese, and then cooking it until it's harder than the hood of a volkswagen bug does not make it italian food.

 village. pizzeria. where all they're missing is the idiot, and that'd be YOU, if you order from them...

 

i've had much better from both gaspare's and cable car pizza...
author: Andy P.

description: I ordered half Estafeta and half Village Special. I do not like feta cheese on pizza but I just picked it off! The pizza was very good! I ordered to go and I came here in half an hour and the pizza was done. But the restaurant was fairly empty.
author: Janet Z.

description: We went to go see DEVO last night, and every restaurant in the area was packed with a line out the door. We decided to brave this little pizza place (chain?) and were surprised at how good the pizza was. It wasn't the best pizza in town, but it wasn't expensive, the service was on top of things, and aside from the rude obese lady sitting at my back talking about buying a new Hummer (and the fact that she kept jabbing me in the shoulder with her purse even though I moved my seat away from her like a million times), it was an OK place to eat.
author: Sam A.

description: My move from North Beach to the Inner Richmond has one downfall, and that is that my new local Village Pizzeria is not on Van Ness anymore. The one on Clement is just not the same as Van Ness; the pizza is less juicy, less filling, less satisfyingly greasy, while still being greasy. I know that doesn't make sense but I don't have the heart to explain it right now, since I am still mourning the loss of my last local pizzerias. In any case, the good news is this one is a mere two blocks from my door. And... there is always the hope that I will either adapt or lower my standards. The latter seems more likely.
author: Anna S.

description: Love this place! Great pizza and they even deliver inside the Presidio. I like their Sicilian style pizza, which comes in squares instead of slices. Decent salads too and huge brownies for only $1.65 if you're craving something sweet.
author: Ericka A.

description: I used to love this place.  Still like it alot and am a frequent visitor.  However, the service is what is turning me off.  On busy nights, I expect the service to be slow.  I know it's not an excuse but I can understand it.  When it's empty, I just don't get it.  There have been times when I'm literally the only customer in the place and there's not a waiter to be seen.  It leads to an excruciatingly painful experience, especially if you're parked at the meters and having to watch your car like a hawk to ensure you're not ticketed.  I like most of the food, especially the pizza.  It can be hit or miss and tastes much better by the slice (pie crust is much thicker for some reason, even extra large) but some of the other items are pretty good too (salads, sicilian, heroes).  However, I might give the Pac Heights location a try to see if the food is just as good because the service can't be any worse.
author: AZ A.

description: I ate here with a friend last Thursday, as we were out exploring her 'hood in the Inner Richmond. The pizza seemed decent at the time - I created my own and did a slice of artichoke, mushroom, etc. & one piece of the meat lover's (both pieces thick crust), and though I couldn't eat it all, it was delicous. I just wouldn't say it's "out of this world," and I still think I prefer Pizza Orgasmica.
author: Sally M.

description: Consistently good pizza at Clement or Van Ness locations.
author: Bridget T.

description: Village Pizzeria is one of the best pizza joints that I have tried in the city.  Great tasting pasta's, (I recommend the Pene Pesto Chicken!) huge calzones, great pies, with a huge selection of toppings and most importantly a decent selection of beer.
author: Chuy C.

description: Juicy (greasy) pizza! I like it because you can fold 'em and watch the oil spill out. What fun. But seriously, Village P. is solid pie right at Clement and Arguello. The thick crust pizzas are also very good, and they may still have Monday pitcher nights--$2 a pitcher!
author: Patrick G.

description: Not having visiting the actual restaurant, I can say that their delivery service is quite nice. They called to confirm our online order before we even thought of doing it, letting us know that because of recent spinach "issues", we had to adjust our order. They could have just as easily left off the spinach and not told us, so +1 for them. Sadly, I asked for something other than what they gave me, so -1. Delivery was a bit long, especially for the middle of the week and the food was just ok. I'd like to try their pasta sometime, but for pizza, I'll stick with North Beach Pizza.
author: Victoria K.

description:
Naughty TiffanyM for not reviewing this sooner!
Its decently priced for good pizza. They don't skimp on topping amounts or the quality... Beth L. and I died and went to pesto heaven last night customizing their margharita to have red onions instead of green ones.. and adding fresh basil (This could have been OverTheTop, given the pesto base.. but NO); divine. We polished it off in record time, with only delightful 'mmmmm' noises breaking the silence.  The Veggie pizza is also delicious too, I may add. And the hubby adores their BBQ Chicken pizza (which has bacon and cilantro among other things).
Neighborhood delivery is nice when we're too lazy, but you don't want to miss out on beer nights (Monday and Thurs), where they have 4.50 Rolling Rock pitchers and 5.50 Red Tail Ale pitchers. 
Village Pizzeria is a totally different experience than my beloved Gaspare's but so very welcomed to be in my neighborhood making such tasty foods:)
author: Tiffany M.

description: A long list of pizza choices, thin and thick.  A meal can be had for about $5.  Mix Village Pizza with a stop at The Bitter End, and you've got yourself a good night.
author: Jason R.

description: The pizza is wonderful!!!  You get so much for your money and it is all tasty!!!  I am a bit worried because every time I have gone in there is no one there, which is obviously good there is never a wait, but worries me that business isn't going very well.  Blows Giorgio's out of the water, which is only two blocks away.  Go there, enjoy it!
author: matt g.

description: I used to work here for nearly 4 years during high school and college. The owner treated me like family for the most part as this is a Brazilian owned family pizzeria. I enjoyed my co-workers (though there was a high turn over rate) but didn't enjoy always being called in whenever someone proved to be sick or just plain unreliable. One of the best pizza makers I know, Carlos, was not only my co-worker but a good friend and an loyal and hard worker. Sometimes it gets really slow there but beer nights and weekend we made pretty good tips and the place is usually packed when hockey moms book for award ceremonies after a game. The pizza I felt was tasty, I like their sauce and the salads. Ingredients I can say were always fresh and often times I was the one cutting and preparing the toppings so you can BET it was. I stopped working there at the end of 03', you know how it goes..you get married and you have to move. I did get kind of sick of eating pizza while working for a pizza place but after not having it in a few years, I do still kind of crave it. So 4 stars to the memories and for giving me a steady paycheck while my mom and I were on food stamps during high school.
author: Petra S.

description: Pizza is pretty good, large slices. However I've never actually eaten at the place, I've only ordered delivery from there. Love the Hawaiian pizza and more than enough to feed 3 people.
author: Lily K.

description: As for pizza places go this place isn't bad. Their clam pizza is off the hook.  Although I always seem to burn the roof of my mouth when I eat here. Otherwise the service is good and prices are decent.
author: Spooky B.

description: I love this place... It's definately up there on my list of favorite pizza places... Their pesto pizza is to die for!! I go here whenever I'm on Clement and I'm not in the mood for Chinese... Mmmm...
author: Lindsey S.

description: It's a good pizza place. The pizza is good and so are most of the appetizers. One thing I like about the pizza here is that it is very thing, which just makes it taste better. The service isn't the best though. We spilled some water and it then forever to figure out that we spilled water and then they cleaned it in 2 seconds leaving most of the water still on the table. The brownies at this place are good too.
author: Nikita K.

description:
This place is my default dinner place, when I don't feel like cooking or dont feel like walking more than a few steps to get food.  I love that they are on the corner of my block, so i don't even have to cross the street.   I've been eating here for over two years now and just decided to write a review. I think that its taken me so long to have an opinion on this place because I have a deep deep love for New York City pizza. Being from New York my standards are high when it comes to places "claiming" to have New York style pizza.   
Well since i've been eating here for over two years, its safe to assume that i like the place a lot.  I can't really say that it tastes like a NYC slice, but its very close.  Over the years the crust has gotten a lot better, and the sauce and cheese ratio are just about right. On certain days they tend to get cheap on the cheese.  I do love the fact that they offer the different shakers oregano, garlic powder, cheese and crushed red pepper! No New York Style pizzeria would ever go without shakers...especially the garlic powder.   
One word of advice, take out/ delivery is not the best option. Its better to ahve the pizza there and have it fresh out of the oven.
author: Maria B.

description: Eh.  I now realize how much pizza i've eaten in the last couple months.  Village Pizzeria was billed by one of my friends and its neighbors as some of the best pizza in the city.  It's not.  It's fine, unremarkable pizza.
author: Matt S.

description: Somehow my friend and I ended up ordering 2 pizzas from here and we both couldn't finish them. After eating about half of it, I was stuffed. Overall, I'd say it was worth how much I paid for.
author: Jasleen K.

description: Too expensive when all I want is a cheesey pizza from dominoes.  They do have a good selection of random pizzas though which seem to be prevelant in this city.  I just want a good ol fashion piece of normal pizza.  Is that too much to ask!??!  West coat is def no good for pizza in my opinion.
author: Tiffany L.

description: My place for Italian with my brother! We love this place! I usually get my cheese or meat ravioli in pesto and he gets the lasagna. We also get the Cheesy Garlic bread with Pesto. Greasy, but awesome good! I have tried the pizza here once when I wanted a personal size take-out and it's okay, but I rather get pizza at Seniore's. Overall, I like this place for the coziness and food and sometimes, when there's a good game on TV.
author: Jeremy L.

description: I spoke too soon.  They delivered a cold pizza that must have been sitting out too long.  It was very salty and greasy.  The pizza delivery guy complained at how far he had to drive to get to our house, when I clearly asked if they served our area on the phone beforehand.  Forget trying this place!!!  It left me felling sick and bloated.
author: Stephanie K.

description: I wen there, ordered a slice of peperoni pizza.  The service was nice, but the thick crust slice i ordered reminded me of a frozen french bread pizza.
author: Russ B.

description: Good pizza (something about the sauce and cheese...) and great crust. Remember, it takes a village (pizzeria) to raise a child!
author: Bee H.

description: I can't believe there is anyone who would not enjoy Village Pizza's deep dish pizza. I had not been not a deep dish pizza fan, but decided to try it here since they were known for it. It's heaven for your mouth! The tomato sauce is abundant with some tangy flavor that sets off perfectly against the crust and cheese. Soooooo good.
author: carol c.

description: This place (Village Pizzeria at 1 Clement) seems to have had a sister restaurant by the same name at 1243 Van Ness.  It seems that they used to share the same website.  It seems that they have recently "broken up."  If you order a pizza for delivery (either by phone or on the internet), make sure that you are ordering from the store you intend to order from (either 1 Clement or 1243 Van Ness) and not the wrong one, or things will get horribly messed up.
author: John H.

description: We have eaten their pizza twice. Both times we ordered the thin crust pepperoni, and it was good. The thin NY style crust was chewy(not doughy). The sauce was tangy and good, and the cheese was fresh. Overall, the pizza here is better than many other pizza joints in the city, but not quite 5 stars.
author: Joe M.

description: $5.50  for a pitcher of beer and okay prices for the chef's special half pizza.  Watching the Olympics and cheering for the USA while having a drink.  Awesome!
author: Jen C.

description:
Pizza is amazing, salads are good too, love the garlic bread and they have happy hour late on Thursday for draft beer. I like this place. I often walk to it to grab a pint and pizza and watch the Giants game.

Oh, and I've never gotten it but, my friends tell me the pasta rocks!
author: Kristen R.

description: This is delicious pizza. The tomato sauce is tangy and delicious, they don't overdo the cheese (to my taste,) and the crust is just as crispy as it should be as well as flavorful. Add a glass of Mirror Pond on tap and it's a great dinner. My favorite pizza in this area of SF by far! The only drawback for me is the huge TV screen, but I can usually sit with my back to it and ignore it.
author: Leela S.

description:
DON'T ORDER FROM THIS PLACE!!!!!! At least not online

OK, let me start by saying that I never tried their food. Why? Because they never delivered the order that I placed on their webpage. Even though they CHARGED my credit card for it and sent a confirmation email.

When, after 1.5 hour of waiting, I called to ask where my pizza was I was told "oh, yes, we never received this order". There was no - we are sorry - or - if you place the order now on the phone this will be our priority delivery. Seriously nobody even pretended to care!!
author: Agnieszka T.

description: I like this place.  I have always gotten delivery, and it always arrives quick and hot.  The thin crust Hawaiian pizza is the best.  Not greasy and just the right amount of cheese.   I have tried a couple of pasta dishes as well - the lasagna, chicken alfredo and spaghetti with meat balls are all decent, but I would stick with the pizza.  I have not tried the calzones, but I think I will next time after reading some of the reviews.
author: Maya S.

description: I really like the pizza here, and it's a nice, casual atmosphere with a few magazines available to read.  You can order custom made slices here, which is a big hit for me.
author: Ginger M.

description: Village Pizzeria excels at pies with lots of toppings. Great for vegetarians. Their slices leave something to be desired, but their whole pies are simply perfect. The only thing keeping them from getting 5 is that they keep screwing up my orders. Even then, the pizza frigging rocks my world. They have good happy hour deals on beer too.
author: Elias R.

description: I've eaten pizza here a few times, normally ordering by the slice.  So, this review may only apply to ordering pizza by the slice.  It's not very good.  It looks and tastes like leftover pizza that's had ingredients sprinkled over the top and reheated.
author: Richard C.

description: Today I stopped in Village Pizzeria for an early dinner.  Plus, it was raining cats and dogs, so I needed to get out of the elements.  I ordered one of the lunch specials (they serve until 5 p.m.) which consisted of a thin crust slice, a large soda, and a side salad.  The salad was really crisp and fresh, and I really liked the creamy balsamic dressing.  The pizza took a little time, but no complaints here, as it was fresh out of the oven.  It was a little slice of heaven!  Crisp crust, lotsa cheese, fresh musrooms.  Delicious. All for six fiddy.  I have also tried the lasagna many a time.  It is pretty darn good.  It's a large portion, and I always have left overs.  The garlic rolls are really good; they are made like cinnamon rolls (rolled up), and according to the menu, made fresh daily.  On Monday and Thursdays they have beer night where you can get a pitcher of decent beer for like $5.  The catch is, you have to order $5 in food per person.  Of course, this is not a difficult thing to do.
author: Sarah F.

description: i went here last week and had the bacon pizza and the carnivore special and its was really good, but you have to get the sicilian style which is with the thick crust. its soooo good!
author: stacy l.

description: came here right after middle school graduation with my close friends before we don't see each other!!! we all went to different high schools... pizza there was great!!! enough to share with friends!! would like to go there again.. but havent had the chance to!!!
author: Lily T.

description: whenever i'm hungering for some east coast pizza, it's either amici's or village.  but you have to order it with extra cheese or it would almost be like eating cartboard.  they could still use some work on the crust, but the sauce is tasty enough.  really haven't found another one that has come close to the yummy pizzas from east coast.  it can't be helped though.
author: Food Is L.

description:
eh, not my cup of tea for pizza...i ordered 2 slices (1 pep & mushroom & 1 hawaiian, both neopolitan style). the pep & mushroom was super greasy! i know, i know..it's pepperoni..expected to be greasy but not to the point where it drips off a boatload on to my plate!!! i understand that neopolitan style is thin crust style--kinda like NYC pizzas & i like NYC pizzas--but it could barely hold up! and the cheese...where the hell was it??? i didnt see an ounce of gooey cheesy-ness....it was just sauce on a thin crap crust and a terrible hard crust. granted, i ate both slices but i was super hungry. i love thin crust pizzas but i guess it wasnt what i was expecting--the fresh, hand spun thin crusts at the fancy restaurants like Local Kitchen or even at park chow....

nope, sorry  village...i'll stick to my local north beach pizza even tho they have a thick ass crust but at least its yummy cheesyness....
author: Yolanda L.

description: We tried this pizza tonight since they left a circular on our door.  Called for delivery, pizza came nice and fast, but I've got to say, not the best pie in town.  We got a large pepperoni with mushroom.   it arrived cold, greasy and too much garlic.   Also, there was something hard and weird in the shrooms,, maybe plastic.  I think I'll wait for Pasquali's next time.
